intro: Sisyrinchium zamudioi, commonly known as the Zamudio blue-eyed grass, is a flowering plant native to the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It belongs to the family Iridaceae and is characterized by its slender, grass-like leaves and showy blue to purple flowers. The plant typically grows in rocky or sandy soils and thrives in full sun to partial shade. It is a perennial herb that produces small, tubular flowers that attract pollinators such as bees and butterflies. Due to its limited distribution and habitat specificity, it is considered a rare and endangered species.
